elements.content: Reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 5-fluoro-1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (5-F-1,3-bpeb) and 1,3-benzene­dicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2­BDC) under the solvothermal conditions gave rise to a two-dimensional metal–organic framework (MOF) [{Cd2­(5-F-1,3-bpeb)2­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·2H2O] n (1). Compound 1 was postmodified by a photodimerization reaction between 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands to yield [{Cd2­(syn-dftpmcp)­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·H2O] n (syn-dftpmcp = syn-3,4,­12,13-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-8,17-bisfluoro-1,2,­9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane) (2). Compounds 1 and 2 have 2D networks built from linking one-dimensional [Cd2­(1,3-BDC)2] n chains via 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp bridges. After such a post-synthetic modification, compound 2, relative to 1, can probe Al3+ by using a luminescent quenching approach with much higher selectivity and sensitivity.

Compound 1 was postmodified by a photodimerization reaction between 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands to yield [{Cd2(syn-dftpmcp)(1,3-BDC)2}⋅0.5DMF⋅H2O] n  (syn-dftpmcp = syn-3,4,12,13-tetrakis(4-pyridyl)-8,17-bisfluoro-1,2,9,10-diethano[2.2]metacyclophane) (2). Compounds 1 and 2 have 2D networks built from linking one-dimensional [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] n  chains via 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp bridges. After such a post-synthetic modification, compound 2, relative to 1, can probe Al3+ by using a luminescent quenching approach with much higher selectivity and sensitivity.

elements.content: One two-dimensional MOF [{Cd2­(5-F-1,3-bpeb)2­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·2H2O] n undergoes a single-crystal-to-single-crystal photodimerization to yield another two-dimensional MOF [{Cd2­(syn-dftpmcp)­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·H2O] n , which exhibits remarkably enhanced performance in the selective luminescent sensing of Al3+.

elements.content: Post-synthetic modification of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is a powerful tool for functionalizing these porous materials. This involves, for example, conversion of functional groups (e.g., −NH2, −NO2, −N3) within pores, immobilization of catalytic metal sites, metal ion or ligand exchange, and substitution on the aromatic ring of appropriate ligands. These approaches can provide access to new MOFs with desired functionality. Post-synthetic modification involving cleavage or generation of covalent bonds, however, can sometimes lead to the loss of overall single crystallinity. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation of MOFs is still uncommon, but offers the opportunity for fascinating new topologies and a detailed understanding of the relationship between the structures of starting materials and products. Most studied, in this respect, is SCSC [2 + 2] photodimerization that can be achieved with complete regio- and stereospecificity in quantitative yields for substrates with appropriately oriented π bonds. These solid-state transformations have been used to prepare cyclobutanes in molecular ladders and polymers. Hydrogen bonding, metal···metal interactions, π···π stacking, and coordination bonds are used to hold the reactive π bonds in the correct orientation and at an appropriate distance to react under UV or visible light irradiation. Notably, photocycloaddition reactions within MOFs can provide a facile method for post-synthetic modification of the framework with concomitant tuning of physical and chemical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Post-synthetic modification of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is a powerful tool for functionalizing these porous materials. This involves, for example, conversion of functional groups (e.g., -NH2, -NO2, -N3) within pores, immobilization of catalytic metal sites, metal ion or ligand exchange, and substitution on the aromatic ring of appropriate ligands. These approaches can provide access to new MOFs with desired functionality. Post-synthetic modification involving cleavage or generation of covalent bonds, however, can sometimes lead to the loss of overall single crystallinity. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation of MOFs is still uncommon, but offers the opportunity for fascinating new topologies and a detailed understanding of the relationship between the structures of starting materials and products. Most studied, in this respect, is SCSC [2 + 2] photodimerization that can be achieved with complete regio- and stereospecificity in quantitative yields for substrates with appropriately oriented π bonds. These solid-state transformations have been used to prepare cyclobutanes in molecular ladders and polymers. Hydrogen bonding, metal⋅⋅⋅metal interactions, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking, and coordination bonds are used to hold the reactive π bonds in the correct orientation and at an appropriate distance to react under UV or visible light irradiation. Notably, photocycloaddition reactions within MOFs can provide a facile method for post-synthetic modification of the framework with concomitant tuning of physical and chemical properties.

elements.content: Luminescent MOFs have been used as sensors to detect specific inorganic anions, cations, and organic molecules. The introduction of extra functional groups onto a MOF to specifically interact with a particular analyte can increase its sensing selectivity and sensitivity. We and others have prepared many MOFs with bipyridyl-based ligands bearing one or more olefinic groups and found that [2 + 2] cycloaddition could improve the selectivity and sensitivity of the resulting frameworks for detecting toxic analytes. Aluminum­(III) is one of the most common toxic metal ions among those analytes. Aluminum and its alloys are widely used in industry and Al3+ existing in natural water and plants and can easily enter the food chain. The average uptake of Al3+ for the human body is 3–10 mg per day. However, abnormal concentrations of Al3+ have been linked to Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinsonism dementia, osteoporosis, colic, and rickets. Thus, developing methods for the facile detection of Al3+ is highly desirable. The photoluminescent sensing of Al3+ using MOFs with high selectivity and sensitivity has been achieved using MOFs with a tunable channel size, good structural stability, and a large surface area. In this work, we designed and synthesized a new vinyl-based ligand, 5-fluoro-1,3-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene (5-F-1,3-bpeb), which has a fluorine atom on the central phenyl ring. With this ligand and 1,3-benzene­dicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2­BDC), we solvothermally prepared a two-dimensional (2D) Zn­(II)-based MOF [{Cd2­(5-F-1,3-bpeb)2­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·2H2O] n (1), and performed an SCSC [2 + 2] photodimerization yielding another 2D MOF [{Cd2­(syn-dftpmcp)­(1,3-BDC)2}·0.5DMF·H2O] n (2, syn-dftpmcp = syn-3,4,12,13-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-8,17-bisfluoro-1,2,9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane). Compound 1 showed relatively poor selectivity and sensitivity for the luminescent detection of Al3+; however, compound 2, derived by photochemical post-synthetic modification, exhibited a remarkably high selectivity for sensing of Al3+ at the ppb level.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All chemicals were purchased and used as received without prior purification. The synthesis of 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligand was carried out using standard Schlenk techniques. The analytic instruments utilized in this Article are the same as the corresponding ones employed in our previous works.

elements.content: To a 50 mL Schlenk tube containing 1,3-dibromo-5-fluorobenzene (0.75 g, 3 mmol), 4-vinylpyridine (0.78 g, 7.5 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.83 g, 6 mmol) was added (PPh3)2­PdCl2 (0.042 g, 0.06 mmol). The tube was degassed under vacuum and then backfilled with N2 for three times. Deoxygenated N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was added into the tube under N2. The resulting mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 16 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the mixture was added to water (20 mL), extracted three times with CH2Cl2 (15 mL), washed with brine, and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic phase was concentrated under vacuum, and the resulting crude material was purified by silica gel column chromatography (gradient elution with 25–45% EtOAc/petroleum ethers) to give 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligand as a light yellow powder. Yield: 0.91 g (91%). Mp: 215–220 °C. Anal. Calcd for C20H50­FN2: C, 79.45; H, 5.00; N, 9.27%. Found: C, 79.30; H, 5.17; N, 9.36%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 8.59 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H), 7.78 (s, 1H), 7.57 (dd, J = 10.7, 5.4 Hz, 6H), 7.50 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 2H), 7.41 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 164.1, 162.5, 150.6, 144.2, 139.6, 139.5, 131.9, 128.5, 122.7, 121.4, 113.7, 113.5. IR (KBr disk): 3431 (w), 3027 (w), 2359 (w), 1589 (s), 1412 (m), 1352 (w), 1138 (m), 970 (s), 846 (m), 801 (m), 760 (m), 674 (m), 547 (m), 523 (m) cm–1. HRMS Calcd for (C23H19­N4 + H+): 351.1610; found: 351.1625.

elements.content: Two crystal structures of 1 and 2 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The diffraction of 1 and 2 were performed on a Bruker D8-Quest diffractometer using monochromated Mo–Kα radiation. The structures were solved using SHELXL-2014 and were refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL-2017 program. Solvate molecules in 1 and 2 were found to be severely disordered and removed by PLATON/​SQUEEZE. Thermogravimetric (TG) and elemental analyses indicated that these compounds possessed half a DMF, two water (1) or half a DMF, and one water (2) solvent molecules. The pertinent crystallographic data of 1 and 2 are summarized in . Selected structural parameters are listed in Table S1.

Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Two crystal structures of 1 and 2 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The diffraction of 1 and 2 were performed on a Bruker D8-Quest diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. The structures were solved using SHELXL-2014 and were refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL-2017 program. Solvate molecules in 1 and 2 were found to be severely disordered and removed by PLATON/SQUEEZE. Thermogravimetric (TG) and elemental analyses indicated that these compounds possessed half a DMF, two water (1) or half a DMF, and one water (2) solvent molecules. The pertinent crystallographic data of 1 and 2 are summarized in . Selected structural parameters are listed in Table S1.

Ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb was synthesized by Heck reaction of 4-vinylpyridine with 1,3-dibromo-5-fluorobenzene in a high yield using (PPh3)2­PdCl2 as the catalyst. The high resolution mass spectrum of 5-F-1,3-bpeb contained the peak at m/z = 303.1253 corresponding to the monocation signal of [M + H]+ (calculated m/z = 303.1298) (Figure S1). The 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S2) of 5-F-1,3-bpeb exhibited doublets at δ = 8.59/8.58 and 7.58/7.56 ppm for the pyridinyl protons. The signals at δ = 7.78 ppm and 7.52/7.49 ppm were assigned to three protons of the bridging phenyl ring. The resonances of olefinic protons were inequivalent with separate doublets at δ = 7.59/7.55 and 7.43/7.39 ppm. In the Supporting Information, Figure S2 of the 13C NMR spectrum for 5-F-1,3-bpeb shows peaks at δ = 164.1/162.5, 139.6/139.5, 122.7, 113.7/113.5 ppm that were assigned to the phenyl carbons. The two signals at δ = 131.9, 128.5 ppm belonged to two vinyl carbons. The signals of pyridinyl carbons were located at δ = 150.6, 144.2, 121.4 ppm.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectra

Ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb was synthesized by Heck reaction of 4-vinylpyridine with 1,3-dibromo-5-fluorobenzene in a high yield using (PPh3)2PdCl2 as the catalyst. The high resolution mass spectrum of 5-F-1,3-bpeb contained the peak at m/z = 303.1253 corresponding to the monocation signal of [M + H]+ (calculated m/z = 303.1298) (Figure S1). The 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S2) of 5-F-1,3-bpeb exhibited doublets at δ = 8.59/8.58 and 7.58/7.56 ppm for the pyridinyl protons. The signals at δ = 7.78 ppm and 7.52/7.49 ppm were assigned to three protons of the bridging phenyl ring. The resonances of olefinic protons were inequivalent with separate doublets at δ = 7.59/7.55 and 7.43/7.39 ppm. In the Supporting Information, Figure S2 of the 13C NMR spectrum for 5-F-1,3-bpeb shows peaks at δ = 164.1/162.5, 139.6/139.5, 122.7, 113.7/113.5 ppm that were assigned to the phenyl carbons. The two signals at δ = 131.9, 128.5 ppm belonged to two vinyl carbons. The signals of pyridinyl carbons were located at δ = 150.6, 144.2, 121.4 ppm.

elements.content: Mixing Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O and 5-F-1,3-bpeb with 1,3-H2BDC (1:1:1 molar ratio) in DMF/​CH3CN/​H2O at 120 °C produced the 2D MOF 1 in 73% yield. The phase purity of 1 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies (Figure S3). The diffraction peaks of PXRD were consistent with those calculated ones from the single crystal data. As will be discussed below, each pair of coordinated 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands in 1 is aligned almost parallel to one another and the unsaturated CC bonds are separated by a distance of 3.7267–3.9301 Å. These contacts fall within the Schmidt criteria for a [2 + 2] photodimerization. To evaluate its photoreactivity, single crystals and powdered crystalline samples of 1 were put under a Hg lamp (250 W) and were irradiated with UV light (λ = 365 nm) for ca. 4 h. The morphology and transparent appearance of the samples was retained. An X-ray structure determination of reacted single crystals confirmed that 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands in 1 underwent the [2 + 2] photocycloaddition to syn-3,4,­12,13-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)-8,17-bisfluoro-1,2,­9,10-diethano­[2.2]­metacyclophane (syn-dftpmcp), producing another 2D MOF 2 in an SCSC style. Solid-state cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) 13C NMR spectroscopy of 2 (Figure S4) revealed a new signal that corresponded to a cyclobutane ring appearing at δ = 45.85 ppm, whereas the starting material signals (132.05 and 120.05 ppm) corresponding to olefin disappeared. Intriguingly, the transparency and single-crystal nature of 2 could be retained after heating at 250 °C for 15 h. The PXRD patterns of this thermally treated sample matched those of 1 (Figure S3). The CP/MAS 13C NMR spectroscopy of the resulting powder indicated that the olefinic signals (132.05 and 120.05 ppm) went back and replaced the conspicuous cyclobutane chemical shift at 45.85 ppm. These results indicated the reversible transformation from syn-dftpmcp to two 5-F-1,3-bpeb monomers.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 cannot dissolve in water and organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, toluene, hexane, DMSO, DMF, MeOH, and EtOH. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 showed bands characteristic of carboxyl groups at 1660 cm–1 (1) and 1700 cm–1 (2). The absorption at 3404 cm–1 (1) or 3418 cm–1 (2) are attributed to H2O. The weight loss of 8.87% (1) and 6.86% (2) in the TG analysis over the temperature range of 30–200 °C is ascribed to the elimination of DMF and H2O molecules (Figure S5). The overall framework of 1 and 2 was stable until around 305–314 °C, after which the framework quickly ruptured.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in the P1̅ space group. Their asymmetric units contain one [Cd­(5-F-1,3-bpeb)­(1,3-BDC)] (1) or [Cd2­(syn-dftpmcp)­(1,3-BDC)2] unit (2). As shown in a,b, the Cd­(II) atom shows the CdO4N2 octahedral geometry, completed by four carboxylate O atoms from three 1,3-BDC ligands plus two N atoms of two 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands. In 1 or 2, two carboxylate groups of the 1,3-BDC ligand exhibit two different coordination modes: linking two Cd­(II) atoms via μ-κ1O:​κ1O′ and bidentate-chelating one Cd­(II) center. Two Cd­(II) ions in both 1 and 2 share two bridging 1,3-BDC ligands to form a centrosymmetrically dimeric unit of [Cd2­(1,3-BDC)2]. These dinuclear secondary building units (SBU) are further interconnected by 1,3-BDC ligands, resulting in a one-dimensional (1D) [Cd2­(1,3-BDC)2] n double chain along the c axis (1) or b axis (2) (Figure S6). Such 1D chains are further linked by 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands to yield a 2D network (c,d). In the crystals of 1 and 2, each 2D sheet is bridged by C–F···π interactions between F and the phenyl rings (3.465 (1), 3.273 (2) Å) of 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp, forming a three-dimensional (3D) net with 1D channels (Figure S7). In 2, the Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances are in the normal ranges of 2.245(4)–2.408(4) Å and 2.296(5)–2.310(4) Å, which are close to the corresponding values in 1 (2.234(3)–2.416(3) Å and 2.293(3)–2.319(3) Å). The Cd···Cd distance in 2 is 4.288 Å, which is slightly longer than the corresponding value in 1 (4.271 Å). The two 5-fluorophenyl rings of two adjacent 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands in 1 are almost parallel. After [2 + 2] cycloaddition, the two 5-fluorophenyl groups of syn-dftpmcp in 2 open like a trumpet and their dihedral angle is 31.148(176)°. PLATON calculation gave the solvent accessible volume of the channel in 1 as 32.1% of the total volume (1033.7 Å3 out of the 3225.0 Å3 per unit cell volume), while that for 2 was 34.2% of the total volume (1101.1 Å3 out of the 3218.3 Å3 per unit cell volume). The porosity of MOFs 1 and 2 was also investigated. As-prepared samples were first soaked in MeOH for 3 days and activated at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h. We observed no obvious N2 absorption at 77 K, but notable CO2 uptake at 273 K (Figure S8). MOFs 1 and 2 showed pore-size distributions centered at 0.61/0.839 nm and 0.84/1.07 nm, respectively (Figure S9).

Crystal Structures of 1 and 2 

Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in the P1̅ space group. Their asymmetric units contain one [Cd(5-F-1,3-bpeb)(1,3-BDC)] (1) or [Cd2(syn-dftpmcp)(1,3-BDC)2] unit (2). As shown in a,b, the Cd(II) atom shows the CdO4N2 octahedral geometry, completed by four carboxylate O atoms from three 1,3-BDC ligands plus two N atoms of two 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands. In 1 or 2, two carboxylate groups of the 1,3-BDC ligand exhibit two different coordination modes: linking two Cd(II) atoms via μ-κ1O:κ1O' and bidentate-chelating one Cd(II) center. Two Cd(II) ions in both 1 and 2 share two bridging 1,3-BDC ligands to form a centrosymmetrically dimeric unit of [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2]. These dinuclear secondary building units (SBU) are further interconnected by 1,3-BDC ligands, resulting in a one-dimensional (1D) [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] n  double chain along the c axis (1) or b axis (2) (Figure S6). Such 1D chains are further linked by 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands to yield a 2D network (c,d). In the crystals of 1 and 2, each 2D sheet is bridged by C-F⋅⋅⋅π interactions between F and the phenyl rings (3.465 (1), 3.273 (2) Å) of 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp, forming a three-dimensional (3D) net with 1D channels (Figure S7). In 2, the Cd-O and Cd-N bond distances are in the normal ranges of 2.245(4)-2.408(4) Å and 2.296(5)-2.310(4) Å, which are close to the corresponding values in 1 (2.234(3)-2.416(3) Å and 2.293(3)-2.319(3) Å). The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance in 2 is 4.288 Å, which is slightly longer than the corresponding value in 1 (4.271 Å). The two 5-fluorophenyl rings of two adjacent 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands in 1 are almost parallel. After [2 + 2] cycloaddition, the two 5-fluorophenyl groups of syn-dftpmcp in 2 open like a trumpet and their dihedral angle is 31.148(176)°. PLATON calculation gave the solvent accessible volume of the channel in 1 as 32.1% of the total volume (1033.7 Å3 out of the 3225.0 Å3 per unit cell volume), while that for 2 was 34.2% of the total volume (1101.1 Å3 out of the 3218.3 Å3 per unit cell volume). The porosity of MOFs 1 and 2 was also investigated. As-prepared samples were first soaked in MeOH for 3 days and activated at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h. We observed no obvious N2 absorption at 77 K, but notable CO2 uptake at 273 K (Figure S8). MOFs 1 and 2 showed pore-size distributions centered at 0.61/0.839 nm and 0.84/1.07 nm, respectively (Figure S9).

elements.content: The photoluminescence spectra of 1, 2, and ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb were measured in CH3CN at ambient temperature (Figure S10). A CH3CN solution of 5-F-1,3-bpeb showed dual emissions with band maxima at λ = 359 and 376 nm upon the excitation at λ = 336 nm. These two emission bands are assigned to the 5-F-1,3-bpeb intraligand n–π* and π–π* transitions, respectively. As observed in Figure S10, the maximum emission wavelengths of MOFs 1 and 2 are located at around 380 nm (1) and 379 nm (2) with one shoulder at about 359 nm (1 and 2) when the excitation wavelength is located at λ = 319 nm. These bands are assigned to ligand-centered emissions.

Photoluminescence Properties and Sensing of Al(III)

The photoluminescence spectra of 1, 2, and ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb were measured in CH3CN at ambient temperature (Figure S10). A CH3CN solution of 5-F-1,3-bpeb showed dual emissions with band maxima at λ = 359 and 376 nm upon the excitation at λ = 336 nm. These two emission bands are assigned to the 5-F-1,3-bpeb intraligand n-π* and π-π* transitions, respectively. As observed in Figure S10, the maximum emission wavelengths of MOFs 1 and 2 are located at around 380 nm (1) and 379 nm (2) with one shoulder at about 359 nm (1 and 2) when the excitation wavelength is located at λ = 319 nm. These bands are assigned to ligand-centered emissions.

elements.content: Finely ground samples of 1 or 2 (1 mg) in CH3CN (2 mL) were investigated for their ability to selectively detect metal cations by exposing these suspensions to the solutions of M­(NO3) n salts (M = Na+, Ag+, Ba2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe3+, Al3+, n = 1, 2, or 3) with the concentration of 1 mmol L–1. The addition of Na+, or Ag+, Ba2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe3+ (1 mmol L–1) ions into the suspensions in CH3CN decreased the luminescence intensity of 1 or 2 slightly ( and Figure S11). In the case of Al3+ (1 mmol L–1), however, the original emission of 1 was slightly decreased but that of 2 was completely quenched. Thus MOF 2 showed higher selectivity than MOF 1 for the detection of Al3+.

elements.content: To evaluate the sensitivity of 2 toward Al3+, the luminescence intensity of 2 (1 mg) dispersed in CH3CN (2 mL) was measured upon the gradual addition of Al3+ (). The emission intensity of 2 in CH3CN was decreased by 96.25% at an Al3+ concentration of 0.08 ppm. The fluorescent quenching efficiency was calculated through the Stern–Volmer equation: I/I 0 = 1 + K SV[Al3+] (0–0.1 ppm), where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of Al3+ and K SV represents the Stern–Volmer quenching coefficient. The Stern–Volmer plots were linear (R 2 = 0.991) over the concentration range 0.01–0.05 ppm. The quenching rate constant K SV was calculated to be 7.93 × 107 L mol–1 (). For 2, the limit of detection (LOD) for Al3+ detection was calculated to be 183 ppb. The LOD of 2 is lower than the level of Al3+ in drinking water (200 ppb) recommended by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. This value was also lower than that for other MOF-based sensors such as {[H2N­(CH3)2]­[Eu­(H2O)2­(BTMIPA)]2·H2O} n (10 ppb; H4B­TMIPA = 5,5′-methylenebis­(2,4,6-trimethyl­iso­phthalic acid)), {[H3O]2­[Eu2.5­(BTB)3­(OAc)0.5­(H2O)3]·2DMA·2.5H2O} n , (105 ppb; BTB3– = 1,3,5-benzene­tribenzoate), {[Ba3­La0.5­(μ3-L)2.5­(H2O)3­(DMF)]·3DMF} n (190 ppb; H3L = p-terphenyl-3,4″,5-tricarboxylic acid), and [Eu2­(N-BDC)3­(DMF)4] n (105 ppb; N-H2DBC = 2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid).

elements.content: Selectivity is critically important for sensors, and the selective sensing property of 2 for Al3+ has been confirmed by performing competitive photoluminescence experiments. As shown in , no remarkable changes in the emissions of 2 are observed in the presence of various metal ions (Na+, Ag+, Ba2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe3+) with a concentration of 0.1 ppm in the absence of Al3+ ion. The addition of competitive metal ions into the CH3CN solution of 2 only caused a slight reduction of photoluminescence intensity. However, the fluorescence was nearly completely quenched upon subsequent addition of Al3+ ion (0.1 ppm), verifying that the Al3+ sensing ability of 2 was independent of the presence of other competitive metal ions in acetonitrile (). We also studied the possible interference by different inorganic anions (Figure S12) and observed no difference when AlCl3, Al­(NO3)3, or KAl­(SO4)2 was used.

elements.content: The underlying mechanism of luminescence quenching by Al3+ was investigated. The UV–vis absorption spectra for solutions of M­(NO3) x in CH3CN were first determined (Figures S10 and S13). The Al3+ solution has no obvious absorption at 336 nm (excitation wavelength of 2), and so quenching is not the result of competitive absorption of this UV irradiation. Moreover, the Al3+ absorption band does not overlap with the excitation band of 2, and so resonance energy transfer can be ruled out. Quenching of the luminescence of 2 by Al3+ may therefore be ascribed to the interaction of the Al3+ ion with the framework of 2. To gain insights into the binding of Al3+ ion with 2, powder samples of 1 or 2 were immersed in 2 mL of 10–3 M Al3+ solutions in CH3CN for 12 h. These samples were then examined by PXRD (Figure S14). The PXRD patterns for 1 did not change; however, the PXRD patterns for 2 revealed several new weak peaks. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) (Figure S15) for a solid sample of 1 after immersion in Al3+ solution was almost identical to that of the original sample. However, upon immersion of 2 in the Al3+ solution, XPS revealed that the F 1s peak at 686.7 eV had shifted slightly to 687.1 eV. The PXRD and XPS results suggested a weak interaction between Al3+ and the F atom of 2. Moreover, the dihedral angle between the two 5-fluorophenyl groups of syn-dftpmcp in 2 is enlarged relative to that of 1, permitting greater interaction of the Al3+ ions with the F atom. Such an interaction may diminish the energy-transfer efficiency of the π–π* transitions and thus lead to luminescent quenching of 2.
elements.clean_text:
Proposed Mechanism for Luminescence Quenching by Al3+ 

The underlying mechanism of luminescence quenching by Al3+ was investigated. The UV-vis absorption spectra for solutions of M(NO3) x  in CH3CN were first determined (Figures S10 and S13). The Al3+ solution has no obvious absorption at 336 nm (excitation wavelength of 2), and so quenching is not the result of competitive absorption of this UV irradiation. Moreover, the Al3+ absorption band does not overlap with the excitation band of 2, and so resonance energy transfer can be ruled out. Quenching of the luminescence of 2 by Al3+ may therefore be ascribed to the interaction of the Al3+ ion with the framework of 2. To gain insights into the binding of Al3+ ion with 2, powder samples of 1 or 2 were immersed in 2 mL of 10-3 M Al3+ solutions in CH3CN for 12 h. These samples were then examined by PXRD (Figure S14). The PXRD patterns for 1 did not change; however, the PXRD patterns for 2 revealed several new weak peaks. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) (Figure S15) for a solid sample of 1 after immersion in Al3+ solution was almost identical to that of the original sample. However, upon immersion of 2 in the Al3+ solution, XPS revealed that the F 1s peak at 686.7 eV had shifted slightly to 687.1 eV. The PXRD and XPS results suggested a weak interaction between Al3+ and the F atom of 2. Moreover, the dihedral angle between the two 5-fluorophenyl groups of syn-dftpmcp in 2 is enlarged relative to that of 1, permitting greater interaction of the Al3+ ions with the F atom. Such an interaction may diminish the energy-transfer efficiency of the π-π* transitions and thus lead to luminescent quenching of 2.

elements.content: We also recorded the time-dependent emission spectra (Figure S16) to investigate the response rate of 2 in the presence of Al3+. A suspension of 1 was treated with 0.03 ppm of Al3+, and then fluorescence spectra were acquired at different times (20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, and 180 s). The fluorescent intensity decrease with increasing time reached the minimum value within about 40 s. For an Al3+ concentration of 0.1 ppm, the emission decreased sharply to 40% of the initial response after about 20 s and was almost completely quenched within 60 s. The sensor could be regenerated by centrifugation, flushing with a Na2EDTA solution, followed by washing with CH3CN and then H2O. PXRD patterns of these regenerated samples were unchanged (Figure S14). No obvious changes in the photoluminescence intensity of 2 occurred even after six cycles of exposure to Al3+ solution and regeneration.

elements.content: A novel luminescent 2D MOF 1 was successfully prepared by the solvothermal reaction of π-electron-rich ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb with Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O and 1,3-H2BDC in DMF/​CH3CN/​H2O. Upon UV light irradiation, compound 1 underwent an SCSC transformation to photoproduct 2, in which each pair of 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands formed dimer syn-dftpmcp. Each Cd­(II) atom in 1 and 2 is linked by 1,3-H2­BDC ligands to generate a [Cd2­(1,3-H2­BDC)2] double chain. These chains are interconnected by 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands to form 2D networks. MOF 2 exhibited much higher sensitivity and selectivity toward Al3+ than did 1 with a detection limit of 183 ppb. The present work is an interesting example of post-synthetic modification by photodimerization to yield a more selective and sensitive chemical sensor.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel luminescent 2D MOF 1 was successfully prepared by the solvothermal reaction of π-electron-rich ligand 5-F-1,3-bpeb with Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and 1,3-H2BDC in DMF/CH3CN/H2O. Upon UV light irradiation, compound 1 underwent an SCSC transformation to photoproduct 2, in which each pair of 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligands formed dimer syn-dftpmcp. Each Cd(II) atom in 1 and 2 is linked by 1,3-H2BDC ligands to generate a [Cd2(1,3-H2BDC)2] double chain. These chains are interconnected by 5-F-1,3-bpeb or syn-dftpmcp ligands to form 2D networks. MOF 2 exhibited much higher sensitivity and selectivity toward Al3+ than did 1 with a detection limit of 183 ppb. The present work is an interesting example of post-synthetic modification by photodimerization to yield a more selective and sensitive chemical sensor.

cln_elements.content:
To a 50 mL Schlenk tube containing 1,3-dibromo-5-fluorobenzene (0.75 g, 3 mmol), 4-vinylpyridine (0.78 g, 7.5 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.83 g, 6 mmol) was added (PPh3)2­PdCl2 (0.042 g, 0.06 mmol). The tube was degassed under vacuum and then backfilled with N2 for three times. Deoxygenated N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was added into the tube under N2. The resulting mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 16 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the mixture was added to water (20 mL), extracted three times with CH2Cl2 (15 mL), washed with brine, and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic phase was concentrated under vacuum, and the resulting crude material was purified by silica gel column chromatography (gradient elution with 25–45% EtOAc/petroleum ethers) to give 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligand as a light yellow powder. Yield: 0.91 g (91%). Mp: 215–220 °C. Anal. Calcd for C20H50­FN2: C, 79.45; H, 5.00; N, 9.27%. Found: C, 79.30; H, 5.17; N, 9.36%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 8.59 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H), 7.78 (s, 1H), 7.57 (dd, J = 10.7, 5.4 Hz, 6H), 7.50 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 2H), 7.41 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 164.1, 162.5, 150.6, 144.2, 139.6, 139.5, 131.9, 128.5, 122.7, 121.4, 113.7, 113.5. IR (KBr disk): 3431 (w), 3027 (w), 2359 (w), 1589 (s), 1412 (m), 1352 (w), 1138 (m), 970 (s), 846 (m), 801 (m), 760 (m), 674 (m), 547 (m), 523 (m) cm–1. HRMS Calcd for (C23H19­N4 + H+): 351.1610; found: 351.1625.

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(5-F-1,3-bpeb)<sub>2</sub>(1,3-BDC)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>·0.5DMF·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of 5-F-1,3-bpeb (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,3-H2BDC (21 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), CH3CN (2 mL), and H2O (4 mL) in a sealed Pyrex glass tube (25 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) was heated at 120 °C for 36 h. White crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 68 mg (73%). Anal. Calcd for C57.5­H45.5­Cd2F2N4.5­O10.5: C, 56.13; H, 3.73%; N, 5.12. Found: C, 56.13; H, 3.90%; N, 4.77. IR (KBr disk): 3404 (m), 1660 (m), 1608 (s), 1556 (m), 1428­(m), 1383 (s), 1137 (m), 1017 (m), 959 (m), 847 (m), 748 (m), 719 (m), 676 (w), 537 (w), 513 (m) cm–1.

Synthesis of 5-Fluoro-1,3-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene (5-F-1,3-bpeb)

To a 50 mL Schlenk tube containing 1,3-dibromo-5-fluorobenzene (0.75 g, 3 mmol), 4-vinylpyridine (0.78 g, 7.5 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.83 g, 6 mmol) was added (PPh3)2PdCl2 (0.042 g, 0.06 mmol). The tube was degassed under vacuum and then backfilled with N2 for three times. Deoxygenated N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was added into the tube under N2. The resulting mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 16 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the mixture was added to water (20 mL), extracted three times with CH2Cl2 (15 mL), washed with brine, and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic phase was concentrated under vacuum, and the resulting crude material was purified by silica gel column chromatography (gradient elution with 25-45% EtOAc/petroleum ethers) to give 5-F-1,3-bpeb ligand as a light yellow powder. Yield: 0.91 g (91%). Mp: 215-220 °C. Anal. Calcd for C20H50FN2: C, 79.45; H, 5.00; N, 9.27%. Found: C, 79.30; H, 5.17; N, 9.36%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 8.59 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H), 7.78 (s, 1H), 7.57 (dd, J = 10.7, 5.4 Hz, 6H), 7.50 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 2H), 7.41 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 164.1, 162.5, 150.6, 144.2, 139.6, 139.5, 131.9, 128.5, 122.7, 121.4, 113.7, 113.5. IR (KBr disk): 3431 (w), 3027 (w), 2359 (w), 1589 (s), 1412 (m), 1352 (w), 1138 (m), 970 (s), 846 (m), 801 (m), 760 (m), 674 (m), 547 (m), 523 (m) cm-1. HRMS Calcd for (C23H19N4 + H+): 351.1610; found: 351.1625.

Synthesis of {[Cd2(5-F-1,3-bpeb)2(1,3-BDC)2] n ⋅0.5DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1)

A mixture of 5-F-1,3-bpeb (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,3-H2BDC (21 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), CH3CN (2 mL), and H2O (4 mL) in a sealed Pyrex glass tube (25 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) was heated at 120 °C for 36 h. White crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 68 mg (73%). Anal. Calcd for C57.5H45.5Cd2F2N4.5O10.5: C, 56.13; H, 3.73%; N, 5.12. Found: C, 56.13; H, 3.90%; N, 4.77. IR (KBr disk): 3404 (m), 1660 (m), 1608 (s), 1556 (m), 1428(m), 1383 (s), 1137 (m), 1017 (m), 959 (m), 847 (m), 748 (m), 719 (m), 676 (w), 537 (w), 513 (m) cm-1.

The as-synthesized crystals of 1 (0.5 g) were placed between glass slides and irradiated with a 250 W Hg lamp (λ = 365 nm) for approximately 4 h to form yellow crystals of 2 (100% yield based on 1). Anal. Calcd for C57.5H43.5Cd2F2N4.5O9.5: C, 56.97; H, 3.62%; N, 5.20. Found: C, 56.54; H, 3.95%; N, 4.78. cln_elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 cannot dissolve in water and organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, toluene, hexane, DMSO, DMF, MeOH, and EtOH. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 showed bands characteristic of carboxyl groups at 1660 cm–1 (1) and 1700 cm–1 (2). The absorption at 3404 cm–1 (1) or 3418 cm–1 (2) are attributed to H2O. The weight loss of 8.87% (1) and 6.86% (2) in the TG analysis over the temperature range of 30–200 °C is ascribed to the elimination of DMF and H2O molecules (Figure S5). The overall framework of 1 and 2 was stable until around 305–314 °C, after which the framework quickly ruptured.
